The claim was made by Democratic state S: Mike Romano in a November 8 op-ed in the Charleston Gazette-Mail.
The claim was based on official U: S. Census Bureau data for poverty by state in 2017.
The U: S. Census Bureau's American Community Survey data was used for the statewide poverty statistic, which was considered more reliable due to its larger sample size.
The claim was verified to be true: as West Virginia had the fourth-highest poverty rate of any state in 2017, at 19.1 percent.
